versionA.text:
This is part 3, each of you can only request one information, so it is encouraged to come up with a plan with your partner before starting solving the question. 
 
 24 stroke patients performed a maze task. The mean number of trials for success was x with standard deviation s. If the population mean for this task is μ, what is the calculated value for t? 
 
 The following formula may be useful: t = (X‾ - μ0) / (s / √n), where X‾ is the sample mean, μ0 represents the population mean, s is the standard deviation of the sample and n stands for the size of the sample. 
 
 You and your partner can each select one piece of information from the following:

hint.a: x: the mean number of trials in the sample
hint.d: x-μ: The difference between the mean number of trials for success and the population mean

versionB.text:
This is part 3, each of you can only request one information, so it is encouraged to come up with a plan with your partner before starting solving the question. 
 
 24 stroke patients performed a maze task. The mean number of trials for success was x with standard deviation s. If the population mean for this task is μ, what is the calculated value for t? 
 
 The following formula may be useful: t = (X‾ - μ0) / (s / √n), where X‾ is the sample mean, μ0 represents the population mean, s is the standard deviation of the sample and n stands for the size of the sample.  
 
 You and your partner can each select one piece of information from the following:

hint.a: x: the mean number of trials in the sample (x)
hint.d: x-μ: The difference between the mean number of trials for success and the population mean
